Why not reuse the pkgId?
It should the same ideally - but there is a chance theoretically that we retrieved wrong one... So I'm returning the retrieved one to be sure. Adding a validation is probably better...

If getPackageRecipe then that is a bigger problem. So I don't see how we can retrieve wrong Ids when we are passing the same as argument. My concern was only to not allocae unncessary memory. Even though GC may collect the unused pkgId but its an overhead?

It is... Right now if we have a bug and we are retrieving a totally wrong version, we don't fail anywhere. By having the encapsulation, I also want PackageStore to be more protective by validating this.
But I agree with you that the validation should probably be added in the getPackageRecipe instead of there. Will change it to use the input~

Why is it called PackageLoadingException? It has nothing to do with "load package". Maybe have a generic PackageIOException?

... Yeah. The exceptions were from the initial version and next step is to refine them.
I also had the same thought while reviewing Rahul's #191. We were having LoadingException even while downloading a recipe, which doesn't make sense.
PackageIOException or PackageParsingException would be more appropriate.
Added a TODO for refactoring PackageLoadingException.
Why need both getPackageRecipe and findPackageRecipe?

This is more a useful naming convention (if we agree as a team 😛). I added this as "Team's ask" in our coding practice doc so maybe we could have an agreement...
Callers use get if it expect it to exist, and should handle PackageLoadingException.
On the other hand, callers use find if it doesn't expect one to exist and use the 'Optional' returned to do branching logic, instead of branching on an PackageLoadingException, because it is not an exception.
Why sort?
Because the File::listFiles does not guarantee the order. The intention was to return a sorted list... i.e. ["pkg-1.0.0", "pkg-2.0.0"]...
That's not going to give you the right order once versions (or minor or patch) is greater than 9. If we need it to be ordered by version I think we need a custom comparator.
Good catch. I didn't pay enough attention when copying this logic. Will do.
I will do this after we changed the recipe folder structure per Feng's comment below, because the filename will only contain the version. Should be easier.

This method does a o(n) lookup, do we have to have this method? The other way is to organize the recipe files as
recipes/Foo/1.0.recipe

lol. I was thinking about the exact same thing. We should probably change the folder structure from the original design. Because it doesn't make sense to go through the entire package store's recipes to find versions for one package.
This method is a good interface to query/list satisfying package versions locally.
